thread.title: LaMarcus Aldridge: 'Wrong' for Warriors to have so many more All-Stars than Spurs
thread.title_full: LaMarcus Aldridge: 'Wrong' for Warriors to have so many more All-Stars than Spurs

author: Jordan Heck (jordan.heck@performgroup.com)
title: LaMarcus Aldridge: 'Wrong' for Warriors to have so many more All-Stars than Spurs
text:
February 14, 2017 8:02am EST February 14, 2017 8:02am EST Basketball, NBA, News, English LaMarcus Aldridge feels like there should be more Spurs represented in the All-Star game. LaMarcus Aldridge (Getty Images) 
Updated at 8:02 a.m. ET 
Updated at 8:02 a.m. ET 
The Warriors' starting lineup is made up almost entirely of All-Stars, and LaMarcus Aldridge feels like the Spurs are pretty good, too. 
He has somewhat of a point considering the 41-13 Spurs aren't too far behind the 46-8 Warriors. But the voting process didn't agree with him as the Warriors have four members of their team represented at the All-Star game while the Spurs have just one. 
MORE: Players hate the Warriors and other observations from All-Star voting 
“I’m older, so I’m not going to come home and be mad or anything,” Aldridge told The Vertical . “But I do think that it was wrong for Golden State to have four [All-Stars] and we’re a few games behind and only have one. It is what it is. I’m in this position and I’m going to enjoy my break and just come back fresh.” 
The Warriors' All-Stars are who you'd expect: Stephen Curry, Kevin Durant, Draymond Green and Klay Thompson. The Spurs' lone star is Kawhi Leonard. 
While San Antonio does have a great team, you can pretty much leave it at that. Leonard deserved the All-Star nod, but it's hard to give it to anyone else on the roster. The Warriors, meanwhile, have four players who obviously earned their bids. Watch This
